title: Valley Gardens Walking Route

images.title: Colin Smith / Valley Gardens, Landscape Garden
images.caption: Valley Gardens, Landscape Garden. 250 acres of landscaped garden on the northern shore of Virginia Water. Rhododendrons line many of the winding paths

images.title: The Heather Gardens by Len Williams, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Heather Gardens

images.title: don cload / County Boundary, Windsor Great Park
images.caption: County Boundary, Windsor Great Park. The border between Surrey and Berkshire follows the ditch along this valley from Virginia Water lake.

images.title: Colin Smith / The Head of Main Valley
images.caption: The Head of Main Valley. Dwarf daffodils on the meadow in Main Valley and the trees with spring blossom are a great attraction for visitors to Valley Gardens, Windsor Great Park.

images.title: Colin Smith / Spring in the Valley Gardens
images.caption: Spring in the Valley Gardens. Magnolia and rhododendrons bloom in spring within the large landscaped garden

images.title: Andrew Smith / The banks of Virginia Water in Valley Gardens
images.caption: The banks of Virginia Water in Valley Gardens

images.title: The Punch Bowl by Stuart Logan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Punch Bowl

images.title: Colin Smith / Botany Bay Ride
images.caption: Botany Bay Ride. Wide sandy track in Valley Gardens. It leads down to Botany Bay on the northern shore of Virginia Water. The ride is lined by rhododendrons and ornamental trees like magnolia and redwood.

description: Explore these stunning, colourful gardens located in Windsor Great Park. There are 250 acres of landscaped gardens and woodlands to explore using a series of well defined walking trails. One of the main highlights on the walk is the amazing Punch Bowl. This area of the gardens contains numerous multi-coloured azaleas, exploding into a riot of colour in the springtime. Other plants/trees include Magnolia, Mahonia, Pernettya, Rhododendron Species, Glenn Dale azaleas, hardy ferns, Ilex and Dwarf conifers. This walk starts at the eastern end of the gardens next to the car park. You then pass the 100 foot high totem pole and the Wick Pond as you head to High Flyer's Hill. You return passing the Polo grounds where you may be able to watch a match. You then pass the pretty Obelisk pond before returning to the start point. If you would like to continue your walk you could head to the nearby Virginia Water Lake where you'll find a delightful lakeside trail.
display_address: Wick Road, Egham Wick, Englefield Green, Runnymede, Surrey, England, TW20 0HN, United Kingdom
